examples.text: She was inclined to trust him.
He writes only when he feels inclined to.
There'll be time for a swim if you **feel so inclined**.
Advertising aims to make people feel favorably inclined toward products.
I didn't know you were that way inclined (= interested in such things).

definitions.definition: tending to do something; likely to do something

examples.text: They'll be more inclined to listen if you don't shout.
people who are naturally inclined to melancholy
She's rather inclined to become impatient.

definitions.definition: used when you are expressing an opinion but do not want to express it very strongly
definitions.sensetop: inclined to agree, believe, think, etc.

examples.text: I'm inclined to agree with you.
I'm half inclined to believe him.

definitions.definition: having a natural ability for something; preferring to do something

examples.text: The club was a notorious hang-out for the criminally inclined.
